user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ModuleLoad_Static:
```c
int32 OS_ModuleLoad_Static(const char *ModuleName)
{
    int32                      return_code = OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND;
    OS_static_symbol_record_t *StaticSym   = OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE;

    while (StaticSym != NULL)
    {
        if (StaticSym->Name == NULL)
        {
            /* end of list  */
            break;
        }
        if (StaticSym->Module != NULL && strcmp(StaticSym->Module, ModuleName) == 0)
        {
            /* found matching module name */
            return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            break;
        }

        ++StaticSym;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ModuleLoad_Static:
typedef const struct
{
    const char *Name;
    void (*Address)(void);
    const char *Module;
} OS_static_symbol_record_t
...
#define OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE OS_STATIC_SYMBOL_TABLE
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND (-17)
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No language/compiler extensions are used in the provided code fragment. The constructs present are all standard C: typedef of a const-qualified anonymous struct (valid C), pointer declaration and initialization from a macro (OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE expands to a symbol but the macro itself is not shown as an extension), pointer comparison with NULL, use of strcmp from the C library, pointer increment (++StaticSym), function pointer member type (void (*Address)(void)), and use of integer macros for error/success codes. None of these are compiler-specific extensions per common compiler documentation.

Notes for reviewers: the only items outside the shown code that could potentially involve extensions are how OS_STATIC_SYMBOL_TABLE (the macro behind OS_STATIC_SYMTABLE_SOURCE) is defined or any attributes applied where that symbol is declared (for example compiler-specific section attributes, pragmas, or nonstandard linkage annotations). Those definitions are not part of the supplied code, so they are not flagged here. If OS_STATIC_SYMBOL_TABLE or related declarations use compiler-specific attributes (e.g., __attribute__((...)), _Pragma with vendor extensions, __declspec, or other documented extensions), those should be inspected separately.
